/* This is like `ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE` but is constant time */
16
#define ECMULT_CONST_TABLE_GET_GE(r,pre,n,w) do { \
17
    int m = 0; \
18
    /* Extract the sign-bit for a constant time absolute-value. */ \
19
    int mask = (n) >> (sizeof(n) * CHAR_BIT - 1); \
20
    int abs_n = ((n) + mask) ^ mask; \
21
    int idx_n = abs_n >> 1; \
22
    secp256k1_fe neg_y; \
23
    VERIFY_CHECK(((n) & 1) == 1); \
24
    VERIFY_CHECK((n) >= -((1 << ((w)-1)) - 1)); \
25
    VERIFY_CHECK((n) <=  ((1 << ((w)-1)) - 1)); \
26
    VERIFY_SETUP(secp256k1_fe_clear(&(r)->x)); \
27
    VERIFY_SETUP(secp256k1_fe_clear(&(r)->y)); \
28
    /* Unconditionally set r->x = (pre)[m].x. r->y = (pre)[m].y. because it's either the correct one \
29
     * or will get replaced in the later iterations, this is needed to make sure `r` is initialized. */ \
30
    (r)->x = (pre)[m].x; \
31
    (r)->y = (pre)[m].y; \
32
    for (m = 1; m < ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(w); m++) { \
33
        /* This loop is used to avoid secret data in array indices. See
34
         * the comment in ecmult_gen_impl.h for rationale. */ \
35
        secp256k1_fe_cmov(&(r)->x, &(pre)[m].x, m == idx_n); \
36
        secp256k1_fe_cmov(&(r)->y, &(pre)[m].y, m == idx_n); \
37
    } \
38
    (r)->infinity = 0; \
39
    secp256k1_fe_negate(&neg_y, &(r)->y, 1); \
40
    secp256k1_fe_cmov(&(r)->y, &neg_y, (n) != abs_n); \
41
} while(0)
42
43
44
/** Convert a number to WNAF notation.
45
 *  The number becomes represented by sum(2^{wi} * wnaf[i], i=0..WNAF_SIZE(w)+1) - return_val.
46
 *  It has the following guarantees:
47
 *  - each wnaf[i] an odd integer between -(1 << w) and (1 << w)
48
 *  - each wnaf[i] is nonzero
49
 *  - the number of words set is always WNAF_SIZE(w) + 1
50
 *
51
 *  Adapted from `The Width-w NAF Method Provides Small Memory and Fast Elliptic Scalar
52
 *  Multiplications Secure against Side Channel Attacks`, Okeya and Tagaki. M. Joye (Ed.)
53
 *  CT-RSA 2003, LNCS 2612, pp. 328-443, 2003. Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2003
54
 *
55
 *  Numbers reference steps of `Algorithm SPA-resistant Width-w NAF with Odd Scalar` on pp. 335
56
 */
57
0
static int secp256k1_wnaf_const(int *wnaf, const secp256k1_scalar *scalar, int w, int size) {
58
0
    int global_sign;
59
0
    int skew = 0;
60
0
    int word = 0;
61
0
62
0
    /* 1 2 3 */
63
0
    int u_last;
64
0
    int u;
65
0
66
0
    int flip;
67
0
    int bit;
68
0
    secp256k1_scalar s;
69
0
    int not_neg_one;
70
0
71
0
    VERIFY_CHECK(w > 0);
72
0
    VERIFY_CHECK(size > 0);
73
0
74
0
    /* Note that we cannot handle even numbers by negating them to be odd, as is
75
0
     * done in other implementations, since if our scalars were specified to have
76
0
     * width < 256 for performance reasons, their negations would have width 256
77
0
     * and we'd lose any performance benefit. Instead, we use a technique from
78
0
     * Section 4.2 of the Okeya/Tagaki paper, which is to add either 1 (for even)
79
0
     * or 2 (for odd) to the number we are encoding, returning a skew value indicating
80
0
     * this, and having the caller compensate after doing the multiplication.
81
0
     *
82
0
     * In fact, we _do_ want to negate numbers to minimize their bit-lengths (and in
83
0
     * particular, to ensure that the outputs from the endomorphism-split fit into
84
0
     * 128 bits). If we negate, the parity of our number flips, inverting which of
85
0
     * {1, 2} we want to add to the scalar when ensuring that it's odd. Further
86
0
     * complicating things, -1 interacts badly with `secp256k1_scalar_cadd_bit` and
87
0
     * we need to special-case it in this logic. */
88
0
    flip = secp256k1_scalar_is_high(scalar);
89
0
    /* We add 1 to even numbers, 2 to odd ones, noting that negation flips parity */
90
0
    bit = flip ^ !secp256k1_scalar_is_even(scalar);
91
0
    /* We check for negative one, since adding 2 to it will cause an overflow */
92
0
    secp256k1_scalar_negate(&s, scalar);
93
0
    not_neg_one = !secp256k1_scalar_is_one(&s);
94
0
    s = *scalar;
95
0
    secp256k1_scalar_cadd_bit(&s, bit, not_neg_one);
96
0
    /* If we had negative one, flip == 1, s.d[0] == 0, bit == 1, so caller expects
97
0
     * that we added two to it and flipped it. In fact for -1 these operations are
98
0
     * identical. We only flipped, but since skewing is required (in the sense that
99
0
     * the skew must be 1 or 2, never zero) and flipping is not, we need to change
100
0
     * our flags to claim that we only skewed. */
101
0
    global_sign = secp256k1_scalar_cond_negate(&s, flip);
102
0
    global_sign *= not_neg_one * 2 - 1;
103
0
    skew = 1 << bit;
104
0
105
0
    /* 4 */
106
0
    u_last = secp256k1_scalar_shr_int(&s, w);
107
0
    do {
108
0
        int even;
109
0
110
0
        /* 4.1 4.4 */
111
0
        u = secp256k1_scalar_shr_int(&s, w);
112
0
        /* 4.2 */
113
0
        even = ((u & 1) == 0);
114
0
        /* In contrast to the original algorithm, u_last is always > 0 and
115
0
         * therefore we do not need to check its sign. In particular, it's easy
116
0
         * to see that u_last is never < 0 because u is never < 0. Moreover,
117
0
         * u_last is never = 0 because u is never even after a loop
118
0
         * iteration. The same holds analogously for the initial value of
119
0
         * u_last (in the first loop iteration). */
120
0
        VERIFY_CHECK(u_last > 0);
121
0
        VERIFY_CHECK((u_last & 1) == 1);
122
0
        u += even;
123
0
        u_last -= even * (1 << w);
124
0
125
0
        /* 4.3, adapted for global sign change */
126
0
        wnaf[word++] = u_last * global_sign;
127
0
128
0
        u_last = u;
129
0
    } while (word * w < size);
130
0
    wnaf[word] = u * global_sign;
131
0
132
0
    VERIFY_CHECK(secp256k1_scalar_is_zero(&s));
133
0
    VERIFY_CHECK(word == WNAF_SIZE_BITS(size, w));
134
0
    return skew;
135
0
}
136
137
0
static void secp256k1_ecmult_const(secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_ge *a, const secp256k1_scalar *scalar, int size) {
138
0
    secp256k1_ge pre_a[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
139
0
    secp256k1_ge tmpa;
140
0
    secp256k1_fe Z;
141
0
142
0
    int skew_1;
143
0
    secp256k1_ge pre_a_lam[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
144
0
    int wnaf_lam[1 + WNAF_SIZE(WINDOW_A - 1)];
145
0
    int skew_lam;
146
0
    secp256k1_scalar q_1, q_lam;
147
0
    int wnaf_1[1 + WNAF_SIZE(WINDOW_A - 1)];
148
0
149
0
    int i;
150
0
151
0
    /* build wnaf representation for q. */
152
0
    int rsize = size;
153
0
    if (size > 128) {
154
0
        rsize = 128;
155
0
        /* split q into q_1 and q_lam (where q = q_1 + q_lam*lambda, and q_1 and q_lam are ~128 bit) */
156
0
        secp256k1_scalar_split_lambda(&q_1, &q_lam, scalar);
157
0
        skew_1   = secp256k1_wnaf_const(wnaf_1,   &q_1,   WINDOW_A - 1, 128);
158
0
        skew_lam = secp256k1_wnaf_const(wnaf_lam, &q_lam, WINDOW_A - 1, 128);
159
0
    } else
160
0
    {
161
0
        skew_1   = secp256k1_wnaf_const(wnaf_1, scalar, WINDOW_A - 1, size);
162
0
        skew_lam = 0;
163
0
    }
164
0
165
0
    /* Calculate odd multiples of a.
166
0
     * All multiples are brought to the same Z 'denominator', which is stored
167
0
     * in Z. Due to secp256k1' isomorphism we can do all operations pretending
168
0
     * that the Z coordinate was 1, use affine addition formulae, and correct
169
0
     * the Z coordinate of the result once at the end.
170
0
     */
171
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_ge(r, a);
172
0
    secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table_globalz_windowa(pre_a, &Z, r);
173
0
    for (i = 0; i < ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A); i++) {
174
0
        secp256k1_fe_normalize_weak(&pre_a[i].y);
175
0
    }
176
0
    if (size > 128) {
177
0
        for (i = 0; i < ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A); i++) {
178
0
            secp256k1_ge_mul_lambda(&pre_a_lam[i], &pre_a[i]);
179
0
        }
180
0
181
0
    }
182
0
183
0
    /* first loop iteration (separated out so we can directly set r, rather
184
0
     * than having it start at infinity, get doubled several times, then have
185
0
     * its new value added to it) */
186
0
    i = wnaf_1[WNAF_SIZE_BITS(rsize, WINDOW_A - 1)];
187
0
    VERIFY_CHECK(i != 0);
188
0
    ECMULT_CONST_TABLE_GET_GE(&tmpa, pre_a, i, WINDOW_A);
189
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_ge(r, &tmpa);
190
0
    if (size > 128) {
191
0
        i = wnaf_lam[WNAF_SIZE_BITS(rsize, WINDOW_A - 1)];
192
0
        VERIFY_CHECK(i != 0);
193
0
        ECMULT_CONST_TABLE_GET_GE(&tmpa, pre_a_lam, i, WINDOW_A);
194
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge(r, r, &tmpa);
195
0
    }
196
0
    /* remaining loop iterations */
197
0
    for (i = WNAF_SIZE_BITS(rsize, WINDOW_A - 1) - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
198
0
        int n;
199
0
        int j;
200
0
        for (j = 0; j < WINDOW_A - 1; ++j) {
201
0
            secp256k1_gej_double(r, r);
202
0
        }
203
0
204
0
        n = wnaf_1[i];
205
0
        ECMULT_CONST_TABLE_GET_GE(&tmpa, pre_a, n, WINDOW_A);
206
0
        VERIFY_CHECK(n != 0);
207
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge(r, r, &tmpa);
208
0
        if (size > 128) {
209
0
            n = wnaf_lam[i];
210
0
            ECMULT_CONST_TABLE_GET_GE(&tmpa, pre_a_lam, n, WINDOW_A);
211
0
            VERIFY_CHECK(n != 0);
212
0
            secp256k1_gej_add_ge(r, r, &tmpa);
213
0
        }
214
0
    }
215
0
216
0
    secp256k1_fe_mul(&r->z, &r->z, &Z);
217
0
218
0
    {
219
0
        /* Correct for wNAF skew */
220
0
        secp256k1_ge correction = *a;
221
0
        secp256k1_ge_storage correction_1_stor;
222
0
        secp256k1_ge_storage correction_lam_stor;
223
0
        secp256k1_ge_storage a2_stor;
224
0
        secp256k1_gej tmpj;
225
0
        secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&tmpj, &correction);
226
0
        secp256k1_gej_double_var(&tmpj, &tmpj, NULL);
227
0
        secp256k1_ge_set_gej(&correction, &tmpj);
228
0
        secp256k1_ge_to_storage(&correction_1_stor, a);
229
0
        if (size > 128) {
230
0
            secp256k1_ge_to_storage(&correction_lam_stor, a);
231
0
        }
232
0
        secp256k1_ge_to_storage(&a2_stor, &correction);
233
0
234
0
        /* For odd numbers this is 2a (so replace it), for even ones a (so no-op) */
235
0
        secp256k1_ge_storage_cmov(&correction_1_stor, &a2_stor, skew_1 == 2);
236
0
        if (size > 128) {
237
0
            secp256k1_ge_storage_cmov(&correction_lam_stor, &a2_stor, skew_lam == 2);
238
0
        }
239
0
240
0
        /* Apply the correction */
241
0
        secp256k1_ge_from_storage(&correction, &correction_1_stor);
242
0
        secp256k1_ge_neg(&correction, &correction);
243
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge(r, r, &correction);
244
0
245
0
        if (size > 128) {
246
0
            secp256k1_ge_from_storage(&correction, &correction_lam_stor);
247
0
            secp256k1_ge_neg(&correction, &correction);
248
0
            secp256k1_ge_mul_lambda(&correction, &correction);
249
0
            secp256k1_gej_add_ge(r, r, &correction);
250
0
        }
251
0
    }
252
0
}

#endif /* SECP256K1_ECMULT_CONST_IMPL_H */
/home/chfast/Projects/ethereum/evmone/build/coverage-clang/_deps/silkpre-src/third_party/secp256k1/src/ecmult_gen.h

/***********************************************************************
2
 * Copyright (c) 2013, 2014 Pieter Wuille                              *
3
 * Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying    *
4
 * file COPYING or https://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.*
5
 ***********************************************************************/
6
7
#ifndef SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_H
8
#define SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_H
9
10
#include "scalar.h"
11
#include "group.h"
12
13
#if ECMULT_GEN_PREC_BITS != 2 && ECMULT_GEN_PREC_BITS != 4 && ECMULT_GEN_PREC_BITS != 8
14
#  error "Set ECMULT_GEN_PREC_BITS to 2, 4 or 8."
15
#endif
16
6.91k
#define ECMULT_GEN_PREC_B ECMULT_GEN_PREC_BITS
17
6.20k
#define ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G (1 << ECMULT_GEN_PREC_B)
18
260
#define ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N (256 / ECMULT_GEN_PREC_B)
19
20
typedef struct {
21
    /* For accelerating the computation of a*G:
22
     * To harden against timing attacks, use the following mechanism:
23
     * * Break up the multiplicand into groups of PREC_B bits, called n_0, n_1, n_2, ..., n_(PREC_N-1).
24
     * * Compute sum(n_i * (PREC_G)^i * G + U_i, i=0 ... PREC_N-1), where:
25
     *   * U_i = U * 2^i, for i=0 ... PREC_N-2
26
     *   * U_i = U * (1-2^(PREC_N-1)), for i=PREC_N-1
27
     *   where U is a point with no known corresponding scalar. Note that sum(U_i, i=0 ... PREC_N-1) = 0.
28
     * For each i, and each of the PREC_G possible values of n_i, (n_i * (PREC_G)^i * G + U_i) is
29
     * precomputed (call it prec(i, n_i)). The formula now becomes sum(prec(i, n_i), i=0 ... PREC_N-1).
30
     * None of the resulting prec group elements have a known scalar, and neither do any of
31
     * the intermediate sums while computing a*G.
32
     */
33
    secp256k1_ge_storage (*prec)[ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N][ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G]; /* prec[j][i] = (PREC_G)^j * i * G + U_i */
34
    secp256k1_scalar blind;
35
    secp256k1_gej initial;
36
} secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context;
37
38
static const size_t SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_CONTEXT_PREALLOCATED_SIZE;
39
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_init(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* ctx);
40
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_build(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* ctx, void **prealloc);
41
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_finalize_memcpy(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *dst, const secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* src);
42
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_clear(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* ctx);
43
static int secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_is_built(const secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* ctx);
44
45
/** Multiply with the generator: R = a*G */
46
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen(const secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* ctx, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *a);
47
48
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_blind(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *ctx, const unsigned char *seed32);
49
50
#endif /* SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_H */
/home/chfast/Projects/ethereum/evmone/build/coverage-clang/_deps/silkpre-src/third_party/secp256k1/src/ecmult_gen_impl.h
Line
Count
Source (jump to first uncovered line)

/***********************************************************************
2
 * Copyright (c) 2013, 2014, 2015 Pieter Wuille, Gregory Maxwell       *
3
 * Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying    *
4
 * file COPYING or https://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.*
5
 ***********************************************************************/
6
7
#ifndef SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_IMPL_H
8
#define SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_IMPL_H
9
10
#include "util.h"
11
#include "scalar.h"
12
#include "group.h"
13
#include "ecmult_gen.h"
14
#include "hash_impl.h"
15
#ifdef USE_ECMULT_STATIC_PRECOMPUTATION
16
#include "ecmult_static_context.h"
17
#endif
18
19
#ifndef USE_ECMULT_STATIC_PRECOMPUTATION
20
    static const size_t SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_CONTEXT_PREALLOCATED_SIZE = ROUND_TO_ALIGN(sizeof(*((secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context*) NULL)->prec));
21
#else
22
    static const size_t SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_CONTEXT_PREALLOCATED_SIZE = 0;
23
#endif
24
25
1
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_init(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *ctx) {
26
1
    ctx->prec = NULL;
27
1
}
28
29
1
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_build(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *ctx, void **prealloc) {
30
1
#ifndef USE_ECMULT_STATIC_PRECOMPUTATION
31
1
    secp256k1_ge prec[ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N * ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G];
32
1
    secp256k1_gej gj;
33
1
    secp256k1_gej nums_gej;
34
1
    int i, j;
35
1
    size_t const prealloc_size = SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_CONTEXT_PREALLOCATED_SIZE;
36
1
    void* const base = *prealloc;
37
1
#endif
38
39
1
    if (ctx->prec != NULL) {
40
0
        return;
41
0
    }
42
1
#ifndef USE_ECMULT_STATIC_PRECOMPUTATION
43
1
    ctx->prec = (secp256k1_ge_storage (*)[ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N][ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G])manual_alloc(prealloc, prealloc_size, base, prealloc_size);
44
45
    /* get the generator */
46
1
    secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&gj, &secp256k1_ge_const_g);
47
48
    /* Construct a group element with no known corresponding scalar (nothing up my sleeve). */
49
1
    {
50
1
        static const unsigned char nums_b32[33] = "The scalar for this x is unknown";
51
1
        secp256k1_fe nums_x;
52
1
        secp256k1_ge nums_ge;
53
1
        int r;
54
1
        r = secp256k1_fe_set_b32(&nums_x, nums_b32);
55
1
        (void)r;
56
1
        VERIFY_CHECK(r);
57
1
        r = secp256k1_ge_set_xo_var(&nums_ge, &nums_x, 0);
58
1
        (void)r;
59
1
        VERIFY_CHECK(r);
60
1
        secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&nums_gej, &nums_ge);
61
        /* Add G to make the bits in x uniformly distributed. */
62
1
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(&nums_gej, &nums_gej, &secp256k1_ge_const_g, NULL);
63
1
    }
64
65
    /* compute prec. */
66
1
    {
67
1
        secp256k1_gej precj[ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N * ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G]; /* Jacobian versions of prec. */
68
1
        secp256k1_gej gbase;
69
1
        secp256k1_gej numsbase;
70
1
        gbase = gj; /* PREC_G^j * G */
71
1
        numsbase = nums_gej; /* 2^j * nums. */
72
65
        for (j = 0; j < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N; j++) {
73
            /* Set precj[j*PREC_G .. j*PREC_G+(PREC_G-1)] to (numsbase, numsbase + gbase, ..., numsbase + (PREC_G-1)*gbase). */
74
64
            precj[j*ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G] = numsbase;
75
1.02k
            for (i = 1; i < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G; i++) {
76
960
                secp256k1_gej_add_var(&precj[j*ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G + i], &precj[j*ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G + i - 1], &gbase, NULL);
77
960
            }
78
            /* Multiply gbase by PREC_G. */
79
320
            for (i = 0; i < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_B; i++) {
80
256
                secp256k1_gej_double_var(&gbase, &gbase, NULL);
81
256
            }
82
            /* Multiply numbase by 2. */
83
64
            secp256k1_gej_double_var(&numsbase, &numsbase, NULL);
84
64
            if (j == ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N - 2) {
85
                /* In the last iteration, numsbase is (1 - 2^j) * nums instead. */
86
1
                secp256k1_gej_neg(&numsbase, &numsbase);
87
1
                secp256k1_gej_add_var(&numsbase, &numsbase, &nums_gej, NULL);
88
1
            }
89
64
        }
90
1
        secp256k1_ge_set_all_gej_var(prec, precj, ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N * ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G);
91
1
    }
92
65
    for (j = 0; j < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N; j++) {
93
1.08k
        for (i = 0; i < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G; i++) {
94
1.02k
            secp256k1_ge_to_storage(&(*ctx->prec)[j][i], &prec[j*ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G + i]);
95
1.02k
        }
96
64
    }
97
#else
98
    (void)prealloc;
99
    ctx->prec = (secp256k1_ge_storage (*)[ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N][ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G])secp256k1_ecmult_static_context;
100
#endif
101
1
    secp256k1_ecmult_gen_blind(ctx, NULL);
102
1
}
103
104
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_is_built(const secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context* ctx) {
105
0
    return ctx->prec != NULL;
106
0
}

static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_finalize_memcpy(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *dst, const secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *src) {
109
0
#ifndef USE_ECMULT_STATIC_PRECOMPUTATION
110
0
    if (src->prec != NULL) {
111
        /* We cast to void* first to suppress a -Wcast-align warning. */
112
0
        dst->prec = (secp256k1_ge_storage (*)[ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N][ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G])(void*)((unsigned char*)dst + ((unsigned char*)src->prec - (unsigned char*)src));
113
0
    }
114
#else
115
    (void)dst, (void)src;
116
#endif
117
0
}

static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context_clear(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *ctx) {
120
0
    secp256k1_scalar_clear(&ctx->blind);
121
0
    secp256k1_gej_clear(&ctx->initial);
122
0
    ctx->prec = NULL;
123
0
}

1
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen(const secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *ctx, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *gn) {
126
1
    secp256k1_ge add;
127
1
    secp256k1_ge_storage adds;
128
1
    secp256k1_scalar gnb;
129
1
    int bits;
130
1
    int i, j;
131
1
    memset(&adds, 0, sizeof(adds));
132
1
    *r = ctx->initial;
133
    /* Blind scalar/point multiplication by computing (n-b)G + bG instead of nG. */
134
1
    secp256k1_scalar_add(&gnb, gn, &ctx->blind);
135
1
    add.infinity = 0;
136
65
    for (j = 0; j < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_N; j++) {
137
64
        bits = secp256k1_scalar_get_bits(&gnb, j * ECMULT_GEN_PREC_B, ECMULT_GEN_PREC_B);
138
1.08k
        for (i = 0; i < ECMULT_GEN_PREC_G; i++) {
139
            /** This uses a conditional move to avoid any secret data in array indexes.
140
             *   _Any_ use of secret indexes has been demonstrated to result in timing
141
             *   sidechannels, even when the cache-line access patterns are uniform.
142
             *  See also:
143
             *   "A word of warning", CHES 2013 Rump Session, by Daniel J. Bernstein and Peter Schwabe
144
             *    (https://cryptojedi.org/peter/data/chesrump-20130822.pdf) and
145
             *   "Cache Attacks and Countermeasures: the Case of AES", RSA 2006,
146
             *    by Dag Arne Osvik, Adi Shamir, and Eran Tromer
147
             *    (https://www.tau.ac.il/~tromer/papers/cache.pdf)
148
             */
149
1.02k
            secp256k1_ge_storage_cmov(&adds, &(*ctx->prec)[j][i], i == bits);
150
1.02k
        }
151
64
        secp256k1_ge_from_storage(&add, &adds);
152
64
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge(r, r, &add);
153
64
    }
154
1
    bits = 0;
155
1
    secp256k1_ge_clear(&add);
156
1
    secp256k1_scalar_clear(&gnb);
157
1
}
158
159
/* Setup blinding values for secp256k1_ecmult_gen. */
160
1
static void secp256k1_ecmult_gen_blind(secp256k1_ecmult_gen_context *ctx, const unsigned char *seed32) {
161
1
    secp256k1_scalar b;
162
1
    secp256k1_gej gb;
163
1
    secp256k1_fe s;
164
1
    unsigned char nonce32[32];
165
1
    secp256k1_rfc6979_hmac_sha256 rng;
166
1
    int overflow;
167
1
    unsigned char keydata[64] = {0};
168
1
    if (seed32 == NULL) {
169
        /* When seed is NULL, reset the initial point and blinding value. */
170
1
        secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&ctx->initial, &secp256k1_ge_const_g);
171
1
        secp256k1_gej_neg(&ctx->initial, &ctx->initial);
172
1
        secp256k1_scalar_set_int(&ctx->blind, 1);
173
1
    }
174
    /* The prior blinding value (if not reset) is chained forward by including it in the hash. */
175
1
    secp256k1_scalar_get_b32(nonce32, &ctx->blind);
176
    /** Using a CSPRNG allows a failure free interface, avoids needing large amounts of random data,
177
     *   and guards against weak or adversarial seeds.  This is a simpler and safer interface than
178
     *   asking the caller for blinding values directly and expecting them to retry on failure.
179
     */
180
1
    memcpy(keydata, nonce32, 32);
181
1
    if (seed32 != NULL) {
182
0
        memcpy(keydata + 32, seed32, 32);
183
0
    }
184
1
    secp256k1_rfc6979_hmac_sha256_initialize(&rng, keydata, seed32 ? 64 : 32);
185
1
    memset(keydata, 0, sizeof(keydata));
186
    /* Accept unobservably small non-uniformity. */
187
1
    secp256k1_rfc6979_hmac_sha256_generate(&rng, nonce32, 32);
188
1
    overflow = !secp256k1_fe_set_b32(&s, nonce32);
189
1
    overflow |= secp256k1_fe_is_zero(&s);
190
1
    secp256k1_fe_cmov(&s, &secp256k1_fe_one, overflow);
191
    /* Randomize the projection to defend against multiplier sidechannels. */
192
1
    secp256k1_gej_rescale(&ctx->initial, &s);
193
1
    secp256k1_fe_clear(&s);
194
1
    secp256k1_rfc6979_hmac_sha256_generate(&rng, nonce32, 32);
195
1
    secp256k1_scalar_set_b32(&b, nonce32, NULL);
196
    /* A blinding value of 0 works, but would undermine the projection hardening. */
197
1
    secp256k1_scalar_cmov(&b, &secp256k1_scalar_one, secp256k1_scalar_is_zero(&b));
198
1
    secp256k1_rfc6979_hmac_sha256_finalize(&rng);
199
1
    memset(nonce32, 0, 32);
200
1
    secp256k1_ecmult_gen(ctx, &gb, &b);
201
1
    secp256k1_scalar_negate(&b, &b);
202
1
    ctx->blind = b;
203
1
    ctx->initial = gb;
204
1
    secp256k1_scalar_clear(&b);
205
1
    secp256k1_gej_clear(&gb);
206
1
}

#endif /* SECP256K1_ECMULT_GEN_IMPL_H */

#ifndef SECP256K1_ECMULT_IMPL_H
8
#define SECP256K1_ECMULT_IMPL_H
9
10
#include <string.h>
11
#include <stdint.h>
12
13
#include "util.h"
14
#include "group.h"
15
#include "scalar.h"
16
#include "ecmult.h"
17
18
#if defined(EXHAUSTIVE_TEST_ORDER)
19
/* We need to lower these values for exhaustive tests because
20
 * the tables cannot have infinities in them (this breaks the
21
 * affine-isomorphism stuff which tracks z-ratios) */
22
#  if EXHAUSTIVE_TEST_ORDER > 128
23
#    define WINDOW_A 5
24
#    define WINDOW_G 8
25
#  elif EXHAUSTIVE_TEST_ORDER > 8
26
#    define WINDOW_A 4
27
#    define WINDOW_G 4
28
#  else
29
#    define WINDOW_A 2
30
#    define WINDOW_G 2
31
#  endif
32
#else
33
/* optimal for 128-bit and 256-bit exponents. */
34
12
#  define WINDOW_A 5
35
/** Larger values for ECMULT_WINDOW_SIZE result in possibly better
36
 *  performance at the cost of an exponentially larger precomputed
37
 *  table. The exact table size is
38
 *      (1 << (WINDOW_G - 2)) * sizeof(secp256k1_ge_storage)  bytes,
39
 *  where sizeof(secp256k1_ge_storage) is typically 64 bytes but can
40
 *  be larger due to platform-specific padding and alignment.
41
 *  Two tables of this size are used (due to the endomorphism
42
 *  optimization).
43
 */
44
12
#  define WINDOW_G ECMULT_WINDOW_SIZE
45
#endif
46
47
/* Noone will ever need more than a window size of 24. The code might
48
 * be correct for larger values of ECMULT_WINDOW_SIZE but this is not
49
 * not tested.
50
 *
51
 * The following limitations are known, and there are probably more:
52
 * If WINDOW_G > 27 and size_t has 32 bits, then the code is incorrect
53
 * because the size of the memory object that we allocate (in bytes)
54
 * will not fit in a size_t.
55
 * If WINDOW_G > 31 and int has 32 bits, then the code is incorrect
56
 * because certain expressions will overflow.
57
 */
58
#if ECMULT_WINDOW_SIZE < 2 || ECMULT_WINDOW_SIZE > 24
59
#  error Set ECMULT_WINDOW_SIZE to an integer in range [2..24].
60
#endif
61
62
#define WNAF_BITS 128
63
#define WNAF_SIZE_BITS(bits, w) (((bits) + (w) - 1) / (w))
64
#define WNAF_SIZE(w) WNAF_SIZE_BITS(WNAF_BITS, w)
65
66
/** The number of entries a table with precomputed multiples needs to have. */
67
168
#define ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(w) (1 << ((w)-2))
68
69
/* The number of objects allocated on the scratch space for ecmult_multi algorithms */
70
#define PIPPENGER_SCRATCH_OBJECTS 6
71
#define STRAUSS_SCRATCH_OBJECTS 6
72
73
#define PIPPENGER_MAX_BUCKET_WINDOW 12
74
75
/* Minimum number of points for which pippenger_wnaf is faster than strauss wnaf */
76
#define ECMULT_PIPPENGER_THRESHOLD 88
77
78
#define ECMULT_MAX_POINTS_PER_BATCH 5000000
79
80
/** Fill a table 'prej' with precomputed odd multiples of a. Prej will contain
81
 *  the values [1*a,3*a,...,(2*n-1)*a], so it space for n values. zr[0] will
82
 *  contain prej[0].z / a.z. The other zr[i] values = prej[i].z / prej[i-1].z.
83
 *  Prej's Z values are undefined, except for the last value.
84
 */
85
6
static void secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table(int n, secp256k1_gej *prej, secp256k1_fe *zr, const secp256k1_gej *a) {
86
6
    secp256k1_gej d;
87
6
    secp256k1_ge a_ge, d_ge;
88
6
    int i;
89
90
6
    VERIFY_CHECK(!a->infinity);
91
92
6
    secp256k1_gej_double_var(&d, a, NULL);
93
94
    /*
95
     * Perform the additions on an isomorphism where 'd' is affine: drop the z coordinate
96
     * of 'd', and scale the 1P starting value's x/y coordinates without changing its z.
97
     */
98
6
    d_ge.x = d.x;
99
6
    d_ge.y = d.y;
100
6
    d_ge.infinity = 0;
101
102
6
    secp256k1_ge_set_gej_zinv(&a_ge, a, &d.z);
103
6
    prej[0].x = a_ge.x;
104
6
    prej[0].y = a_ge.y;
105
6
    prej[0].z = a->z;
106
6
    prej[0].infinity = 0;
107
108
6
    zr[0] = d.z;
109
48
    for (i = 1; i < n; i++) {
110
42
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(&prej[i], &prej[i-1], &d_ge, &zr[i]);
111
42
    }
112
113
    /*
114
     * Each point in 'prej' has a z coordinate too small by a factor of 'd.z'. Only
115
     * the final point's z coordinate is actually used though, so just update that.
116
     */
117
6
    secp256k1_fe_mul(&prej[n-1].z, &prej[n-1].z, &d.z);
118
6
}
119
120
/** Fill a table 'pre' with precomputed odd multiples of a.
121
 *
122
 *  There are two versions of this function:
123
 *  - secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table_globalz_windowa which brings its
124
 *    resulting point set to a single constant Z denominator, stores the X and Y
125
 *    coordinates as ge_storage points in pre, and stores the global Z in rz.
126
 *    It only operates on tables sized for WINDOW_A wnaf multiples.
127
 *  - secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table_storage_var, which converts its
128
 *    resulting point set to actually affine points, and stores those in pre.
129
 *    It operates on tables of any size.
130
 *
131
 *  To compute a*P + b*G, we compute a table for P using the first function,
132
 *  and for G using the second (which requires an inverse, but it only needs to
133
 *  happen once).
134
 */
135
0
static void secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table_globalz_windowa(secp256k1_ge *pre, secp256k1_fe *globalz, const secp256k1_gej *a) {
136
0
    secp256k1_gej prej[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
137
0
    secp256k1_fe zr[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
138
0
139
0
    /* Compute the odd multiples in Jacobian form. */
140
0
    secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table(ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), prej, zr, a);
141
0
    /* Bring them to the same Z denominator. */
142
0
    secp256k1_ge_globalz_set_table_gej(ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), pre, globalz, prej, zr);
143
0
}
144
145
2
static void secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table_storage_var(const int n, secp256k1_ge_storage *pre, const secp256k1_gej *a) {
146
2
    secp256k1_gej d;
147
2
    secp256k1_ge d_ge, p_ge;
148
2
    secp256k1_gej pj;
149
2
    secp256k1_fe zi;
150
2
    secp256k1_fe zr;
151
2
    secp256k1_fe dx_over_dz_squared;
152
2
    int i;
153
154
2
    VERIFY_CHECK(!a->infinity);
155
156
2
    secp256k1_gej_double_var(&d, a, NULL);
157
158
    /* First, we perform all the additions in an isomorphic curve obtained by multiplying
159
     * all `z` coordinates by 1/`d.z`. In these coordinates `d` is affine so we can use
160
     * `secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var` to perform the additions. For each addition, we store
161
     * the resulting y-coordinate and the z-ratio, since we only have enough memory to
162
     * store two field elements. These are sufficient to efficiently undo the isomorphism
163
     * and recompute all the `x`s.
164
     */
165
2
    d_ge.x = d.x;
166
2
    d_ge.y = d.y;
167
2
    d_ge.infinity = 0;
168
169
2
    secp256k1_ge_set_gej_zinv(&p_ge, a, &d.z);
170
2
    pj.x = p_ge.x;
171
2
    pj.y = p_ge.y;
172
2
    pj.z = a->z;
173
2
    pj.infinity = 0;
174
175
16.3k
    for (i = 0; i < (n - 1); i++) {
176
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_normalize_var(&pj.y);
177
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_to_storage(&pre[i].y, &pj.y);
178
16.3k
        secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(&pj, &pj, &d_ge, &zr);
179
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_normalize_var(&zr);
180
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_to_storage(&pre[i].x, &zr);
181
16.3k
    }
182
183
    /* Invert d.z in the same batch, preserving pj.z so we can extract 1/d.z */
184
2
    secp256k1_fe_mul(&zi, &pj.z, &d.z);
185
2
    secp256k1_fe_inv_var(&zi, &zi);
186
187
    /* Directly set `pre[n - 1]` to `pj`, saving the inverted z-coordinate so
188
     * that we can combine it with the saved z-ratios to compute the other zs
189
     * without any more inversions. */
190
2
    secp256k1_ge_set_gej_zinv(&p_ge, &pj, &zi);
191
2
    secp256k1_ge_to_storage(&pre[n - 1], &p_ge);
192
193
    /* Compute the actual x-coordinate of D, which will be needed below. */
194
2
    secp256k1_fe_mul(&d.z, &zi, &pj.z);  /* d.z = 1/d.z */
195
2
    secp256k1_fe_sqr(&dx_over_dz_squared, &d.z);
196
2
    secp256k1_fe_mul(&dx_over_dz_squared, &dx_over_dz_squared, &d.x);
197
198
    /* Going into the second loop, we have set `pre[n-1]` to its final affine
199
     * form, but still need to set `pre[i]` for `i` in 0 through `n-2`. We
200
     * have `zi = (p.z * d.z)^-1`, where
201
     *
202
     *     `p.z` is the z-coordinate of the point on the isomorphic curve
203
     *           which was ultimately assigned to `pre[n-1]`.
204
     *     `d.z` is the multiplier that must be applied to all z-coordinates
205
     *           to move from our isomorphic curve back to secp256k1; so the
206
     *           product `p.z * d.z` is the z-coordinate of the secp256k1
207
     *           point assigned to `pre[n-1]`.
208
     *
209
     * All subsequent inverse-z-coordinates can be obtained by multiplying this
210
     * factor by successive z-ratios, which is much more efficient than directly
211
     * computing each one.
212
     *
213
     * Importantly, these inverse-zs will be coordinates of points on secp256k1,
214
     * while our other stored values come from computations on the isomorphic
215
     * curve. So in the below loop, we will take care not to actually use `zi`
216
     * or any derived values until we're back on secp256k1.
217
     */
218
2
    i = n - 1;
219
16.3k
    while (i > 0) {
220
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe zi2, zi3;
221
16.3k
        const secp256k1_fe *rzr;
222
16.3k
        i--;
223
224
16.3k
        secp256k1_ge_from_storage(&p_ge, &pre[i]);
225
226
        /* For each remaining point, we extract the z-ratio from the stored
227
         * x-coordinate, compute its z^-1 from that, and compute the full
228
         * point from that. */
229
16.3k
        rzr = &p_ge.x;
230
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_mul(&zi, &zi, rzr);
231
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_sqr(&zi2, &zi);
232
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_mul(&zi3, &zi2, &zi);
233
        /* To compute the actual x-coordinate, we use the stored z ratio and
234
         * y-coordinate, which we obtained from `secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var`
235
         * in the loop above, as well as the inverse of the square of its
236
         * z-coordinate. We store the latter in the `zi2` variable, which is
237
         * computed iteratively starting from the overall Z inverse then
238
         * multiplying by each z-ratio in turn.
239
         *
240
         * Denoting the z-ratio as `rzr`, we observe that it is equal to `h`
241
         * from the inside of the above `gej_add_ge_var` call. This satisfies
242
         *
243
         *    rzr = d_x * z^2 - x * d_z^2
244
         *
245
         * where (`d_x`, `d_z`) are Jacobian coordinates of `D` and `(x, z)`
246
         * are Jacobian coordinates of our desired point -- except both are on
247
         * the isomorphic curve that we were using when we called `gej_add_ge_var`.
248
         * To get back to secp256k1, we must multiply both `z`s by `d_z`, or
249
         * equivalently divide both `x`s by `d_z^2`. Our equation then becomes
250
         *
251
         *    rzr = d_x * z^2 / d_z^2 - x
252
         *
253
         * (The left-hand-side, being a ratio of z-coordinates, is unaffected
254
         * by the isomorphism.)
255
         *
256
         * Rearranging to solve for `x`, we have
257
         *
258
         *     x = d_x * z^2 / d_z^2 - rzr
259
         *
260
         * But what we actually want is the affine coordinate `X = x/z^2`,
261
         * which will satisfy
262
         *
263
         *     X = d_x / d_z^2 - rzr / z^2
264
         *       = dx_over_dz_squared - rzr * zi2
265
         */
266
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_mul(&p_ge.x, rzr, &zi2);
267
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_negate(&p_ge.x, &p_ge.x, 1);
268
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_add(&p_ge.x, &dx_over_dz_squared);
269
        /* y is stored_y/z^3, as we expect */
270
16.3k
        secp256k1_fe_mul(&p_ge.y, &p_ge.y, &zi3);
271
        /* Store */
272
16.3k
        secp256k1_ge_to_storage(&pre[i], &p_ge);
273
16.3k
    }
274
2
}
275
276
/** The following two macro retrieves a particular odd multiple from a table
277
 *  of precomputed multiples. */
278
261
#define ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE(r,pre,n,w) do { \
279
261
    VERIFY_CHECK(((n) & 1) == 1); \
280
261
    VERIFY_CHECK((n) >= -((1 << ((w)-1)) - 1)); \
281
261
    VERIFY_CHECK((n) <=  ((1 << ((w)-1)) - 1)); \
282
261
    if ((n) > 0) { \
283
128
        *(r) = (pre)[((n)-1)/2]; \
284
133
    } else { \
285
133
        *(r) = (pre)[(-(n)-1)/2]; \
286
133
        secp256k1_fe_negate(&((r)->y), &((r)->y), 1); \
287
133
    } \
288
261
} while(0)
289
290
100
#define ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE_STORAGE(r,pre,n,w) do { \
291
100
    VERIFY_CHECK(((n) & 1) == 1); \
292
100
    VERIFY_CHECK((n) >= -((1 << ((w)-1)) - 1)); \
293
100
    VERIFY_CHECK((n) <=  ((1 << ((w)-1)) - 1)); \
294
100
    if ((n) > 0) { \
295
65
        secp256k1_ge_from_storage((r), &(pre)[((n)-1)/2]); \
296
65
    } else { \
297
35
        secp256k1_ge_from_storage((r), &(pre)[(-(n)-1)/2]); \
298
35
        secp256k1_fe_negate(&((r)->y), &((r)->y), 1); \
299
35
    } \
300
100
} while(0)
301

static const size_t SECP256K1_ECMULT_CONTEXT_PREALLOCATED_SIZE =
303
    ROUND_TO_ALIGN(sizeof((*((secp256k1_ecmult_context*) NULL)->pre_g)[0]) * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_G))
304
    + ROUND_TO_ALIGN(sizeof((*((secp256k1_ecmult_context*) NULL)->pre_g_128)[0]) * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_G))
305
    ;
306

1
static void secp256k1_ecmult_context_init(secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx) {
308
1
    ctx->pre_g = NULL;
309
1
    ctx->pre_g_128 = NULL;
310
1
}

static void secp256k1_ecmult_context_build(secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, void **prealloc) {
313
1
    secp256k1_gej gj;
314
1
    void* const base = *prealloc;
315
1
    size_t const prealloc_size = SECP256K1_ECMULT_CONTEXT_PREALLOCATED_SIZE;
316
317
1
    if (ctx->pre_g != NULL) {
318
0
        return;
319
0
    }
320
321
    /* get the generator */
322
1
    secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&gj, &secp256k1_ge_const_g);
323
324
1
    {
325
1
        size_t size = sizeof((*ctx->pre_g)[0]) * ((size_t)ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_G));
326
        /* check for overflow */
327
1
        VERIFY_CHECK(size / sizeof((*ctx->pre_g)[0]) == ((size_t)ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_G)));
328
1
        ctx->pre_g = (secp256k1_ge_storage (*)[])manual_alloc(prealloc, sizeof((*ctx->pre_g)[0]) * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_G), base, prealloc_size);
329
1
    }
330
331
    /* precompute the tables with odd multiples */
332
1
    secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table_storage_var(ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_G), *ctx->pre_g, &gj);
333
334
1

335
1
        secp256k1_gej g_128j;
336
1

337
338
1

339

340

341
1

342
343
        /* calculate 2^128*generator */
344
1
        g_128j = gj;
345
129
        for (i = 0; i < 128; i++) {
346
128

347
128
        }
348
1

354

0

/** Convert a number to WNAF notation. The number becomes represented by sum(2^i * wnaf[i], i=0..bits),
371
 *  with the following guarantees:
372
 *  - each wnaf[i] is either 0, or an odd integer between -(1<<(w-1) - 1) and (1<<(w-1) - 1)
373
 *  - two non-zero entries in wnaf are separated by at least w-1 zeroes.
374
 *  - the number of set values in wnaf is returned. This number is at most 256, and at most one more
375
 *    than the number of bits in the (absolute value) of the input.
376
 */
377
24
static int secp256k1_ecmult_wnaf(int *wnaf, int len, const secp256k1_scalar *a, int w) {
378
24
    secp256k1_scalar s;
379
24
    int last_set_bit = -1;
380
24
    int bit = 0;
381
24
    int sign = 1;
382
24
    int carry = 0;
383
384
24
    VERIFY_CHECK(wnaf != NULL);
385
24
    VERIFY_CHECK(0 <= len && len <= 256);
386
24
    VERIFY_CHECK(a != NULL);
387
24
    VERIFY_CHECK(2 <= w && w <= 31);
388
389
24
    memset(wnaf, 0, len * sizeof(wnaf[0]));
390
391
24
    s = *a;
392
24
    if (secp256k1_scalar_get_bits(&s, 255, 1)) {
393
8
        secp256k1_scalar_negate(&s, &s);
394
8
        sign = -1;
395
8
    }
396
397
764
    while (bit < len) {
398
740
        int now;
399
740
        int word;
400
740
        if (secp256k1_scalar_get_bits(&s, bit, 1) == (unsigned int)carry) {
401
379
            bit++;
402
379
            continue;
403
379
        }
404
405
361
        now = w;
406
361
        if (now > len - bit) {
407
19
            now = len - bit;
408
19
        }
409
410
361
        word = secp256k1_scalar_get_bits_var(&s, bit, now) + carry;
411
412
361
        carry = (word >> (w-1)) & 1;
413
361
        word -= carry << w;
414
415
361
        wnaf[bit] = sign * word;
416
361
        last_set_bit = bit;
417
418
361
        bit += now;
419
361
    }
420
#ifdef VERIFY
421
    CHECK(carry == 0);
422
    while (bit < 256) {
423
        CHECK(secp256k1_scalar_get_bits(&s, bit++, 1) == 0);
424
    }
425
#endif
426
24
    return last_set_bit + 1;
427
24
}
428
429
struct secp256k1_strauss_point_state {
430
    secp256k1_scalar na_1, na_lam;
431
    int wnaf_na_1[129];
432
    int wnaf_na_lam[129];
433
    int bits_na_1;
434
    int bits_na_lam;
435
    size_t input_pos;
436
};
437
438
struct secp256k1_strauss_state {
439
    secp256k1_gej* prej;
440
    secp256k1_fe* zr;
441
    secp256k1_ge* pre_a;
442
    secp256k1_ge* pre_a_lam;
443
    struct secp256k1_strauss_point_state* ps;
444
};
445
446
6
static void secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf(const secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, const struct secp256k1_strauss_state *state, secp256k1_gej *r, size_t num, const secp256k1_gej *a, const secp256k1_scalar *na, const secp256k1_scalar *ng) {
447
6
    secp256k1_ge tmpa;
448
6
    secp256k1_fe Z;
449
    /* Splitted G factors. */
450
6
    secp256k1_scalar ng_1, ng_128;
451
6
    int wnaf_ng_1[129];
452
6
    int bits_ng_1 = 0;
453
6
    int wnaf_ng_128[129];
454
6
    int bits_ng_128 = 0;
455
6
    int i;
456
6
    int bits = 0;
457
6
    size_t np;
458
6
    size_t no = 0;
459
460
12
    for (np = 0; np < num; ++np) {
461
6
        if (secp256k1_scalar_is_zero(&na[np]) || secp256k1_gej_is_infinity(&a[np])) {
462
0
            continue;
463
0
        }
464
6
        state->ps[no].input_pos = np;
465
        /* split na into na_1 and na_lam (where na = na_1 + na_lam*lambda, and na_1 and na_lam are ~128 bit) */
466
6
        secp256k1_scalar_split_lambda(&state->ps[no].na_1, &state->ps[no].na_lam, &na[np]);
467
468
        /* build wnaf representation for na_1 and na_lam. */
469
6
        state->ps[no].bits_na_1   = secp256k1_ecmult_wnaf(state->ps[no].wnaf_na_1,   129, &state->ps[no].na_1,   WINDOW_A);
470
6
        state->ps[no].bits_na_lam = secp256k1_ecmult_wnaf(state->ps[no].wnaf_na_lam, 129, &state->ps[no].na_lam, WINDOW_A);
471
6
        VERIFY_CHECK(state->ps[no].bits_na_1 <= 129);
472
6
        VERIFY_CHECK(state->ps[no].bits_na_lam <= 129);
473
6
        if (state->ps[no].bits_na_1 > bits) {
474
6
            bits = state->ps[no].bits_na_1;
475
6
        }
476
6
        if (state->ps[no].bits_na_lam > bits) {
477
1
            bits = state->ps[no].bits_na_lam;
478
1
        }
479
6
        ++no;
480
6
    }
481
482
    /* Calculate odd multiples of a.
483
     * All multiples are brought to the same Z 'denominator', which is stored
484
     * in Z. Due to secp256k1' isomorphism we can do all operations pretending
485
     * that the Z coordinate was 1, use affine addition formulae, and correct
486
     * the Z coordinate of the result once at the end.
487
     * The exception is the precomputed G table points, which are actually
488
     * affine. Compared to the base used for other points, they have a Z ratio
489
     * of 1/Z, so we can use secp256k1_gej_add_zinv_var, which uses the same
490
     * isomorphism to efficiently add with a known Z inverse.
491
     */
492
6
    if (no > 0) {
493
        /* Compute the odd multiples in Jacobian form. */
494
6
        secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table(ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), state->prej, state->zr, &a[state->ps[0].input_pos]);
495
6
        for (np = 1; np < no; ++np) {
496
0
            secp256k1_gej tmp = a[state->ps[np].input_pos];
497
#ifdef VERIFY
498
            secp256k1_fe_normalize_var(&(state->prej[(np - 1) * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) + ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) - 1].z));
499
#endif
500
0
            secp256k1_gej_rescale(&tmp, &(state->prej[(np - 1) * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) + ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) - 1].z));
501
0
            secp256k1_ecmult_odd_multiples_table(ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), state->prej + np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), state->zr + np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), &tmp);
502
0
            secp256k1_fe_mul(state->zr + np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), state->zr + np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), &(a[state->ps[np].input_pos].z));
503
0
        }
504
        /* Bring them to the same Z denominator. */
505
6
        secp256k1_ge_globalz_set_table_gej(ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) * no, state->pre_a, &Z, state->prej, state->zr);
506
6
    } else {
507
0
        secp256k1_fe_set_int(&Z, 1);
508
0
    }
509
510
12
    for (np = 0; np < no; ++np) {
511
54
        for (i = 0; i < ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A); i++) {
512
48
            secp256k1_ge_mul_lambda(&state->pre_a_lam[np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) + i], &state->pre_a[np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) + i]);
513
48
        }
514
6
    }
515
516
6
    if (ng) {
517
        /* split ng into ng_1 and ng_128 (where gn = gn_1 + gn_128*2^128, and gn_1 and gn_128 are ~128 bit) */
518
6
        secp256k1_scalar_split_128(&ng_1, &ng_128, ng);
519
520
        /* Build wnaf representation for ng_1 and ng_128 */
521
6
        bits_ng_1   = secp256k1_ecmult_wnaf(wnaf_ng_1,   129, &ng_1,   WINDOW_G);
522
6
        bits_ng_128 = secp256k1_ecmult_wnaf(wnaf_ng_128, 129, &ng_128, WINDOW_G);
523
6
        if (bits_ng_1 > bits) {
524
0
            bits = bits_ng_1;
525
0
        }
526
6
        if (bits_ng_128 > bits) {
527
1
            bits = bits_ng_128;
528
1
        }
529
6
    }
530
531
6
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(r);
532
533
770
    for (i = bits - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
534
764
        int n;
535
764
        secp256k1_gej_double_var(r, r, NULL);
536
1.52k
        for (np = 0; np < no; ++np) {
537
764
            if (i < state->ps[np].bits_na_1 && (n = state->ps[np].wnaf_na_1[i])) {
538
126
                ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE(&tmpa, state->pre_a + np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), n, WINDOW_A);
539
126
                secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(r, r, &tmpa, NULL);
540
126
            }
541
764
            if (i < state->ps[np].bits_na_lam && (n = state->ps[np].wnaf_na_lam[i])) {
542
135
                ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE(&tmpa, state->pre_a_lam + np * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A), n, WINDOW_A);
543
135
                secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(r, r, &tmpa, NULL);
544
135
            }
545
764
        }
546
764
        if (i < bits_ng_1 && (n = wnaf_ng_1[i])) {
547
51
            ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE_STORAGE(&tmpa, *ctx->pre_g, n, WINDOW_G);
548
51
            secp256k1_gej_add_zinv_var(r, r, &tmpa, &Z);
549
51
        }
550
764
        if (i < bits_ng_128 && (n = wnaf_ng_128[i])) {
551
49
            ECMULT_TABLE_GET_GE_STORAGE(&tmpa, *ctx->pre_g_128, n, WINDOW_G);
552
49
            secp256k1_gej_add_zinv_var(r, r, &tmpa, &Z);
553
49
        }
554
764
    }
555
556
6
    if (!r->infinity) {
557
5
        secp256k1_fe_mul(&r->z, &r->z, &Z);
558
5
    }
559
6
}
560
561
6
static void secp256k1_ecmult(const secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_gej *a, const secp256k1_scalar *na, const secp256k1_scalar *ng) {
562
6
    secp256k1_gej prej[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
563
6
    secp256k1_fe zr[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
564
6
    secp256k1_ge pre_a[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
565
6
    struct secp256k1_strauss_point_state ps[1];
566
6
    secp256k1_ge pre_a_lam[ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A)];
567
6
    struct secp256k1_strauss_state state;
568
569
6
    state.prej = prej;
570
6
    state.zr = zr;
571
6
    state.pre_a = pre_a;
572
6
    state.pre_a_lam = pre_a_lam;
573
6
    state.ps = ps;
574
6
    secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf(ctx, &state, r, 1, a, na, ng);
575
6
}
576
577
0
static size_t secp256k1_strauss_scratch_size(size_t n_points) {
578
0
    static const size_t point_size = (2 * sizeof(secp256k1_ge) + sizeof(secp256k1_gej) + sizeof(secp256k1_fe)) * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) + sizeof(struct secp256k1_strauss_point_state) + sizeof(secp256k1_gej) + sizeof(secp256k1_scalar);
579
0
    return n_points*point_size;
580
0
}
581
582
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, secp256k1_scratch *scratch, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *inp_g_sc, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void *cbdata, size_t n_points, size_t cb_offset) {
583
0
    secp256k1_gej* points;
584
0
    secp256k1_scalar* scalars;
585
0
    struct secp256k1_strauss_state state;
586
0
    size_t i;
587
0
    const size_t scratch_checkpoint = secp256k1_scratch_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch);
588
0
589
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(r);
590
0
    if (inp_g_sc == NULL && n_points == 0) {
591
0
        return 1;
592
0
    }
593
0
594
0
    points = (secp256k1_gej*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * sizeof(secp256k1_gej));
595
0
    scalars = (secp256k1_scalar*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * sizeof(secp256k1_scalar));
596
0
    state.prej = (secp256k1_gej*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) * sizeof(secp256k1_gej));
597
0
    state.zr = (secp256k1_fe*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) * sizeof(secp256k1_fe));
598
0
    state.pre_a = (secp256k1_ge*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) * sizeof(secp256k1_ge));
599
0
    state.pre_a_lam = (secp256k1_ge*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(WINDOW_A) * sizeof(secp256k1_ge));
600
0
    state.ps = (struct secp256k1_strauss_point_state*)secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, n_points * sizeof(struct secp256k1_strauss_point_state));
601
0
602
0
    if (points == NULL || scalars == NULL || state.prej == NULL || state.zr == NULL || state.pre_a == NULL || state.pre_a_lam == NULL || state.ps == NULL) {
603
0
        secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
604
0
        return 0;
605
0
    }
606
0
607
0
    for (i = 0; i < n_points; i++) {
608
0
        secp256k1_ge point;
609
0
        if (!cb(&scalars[i], &point, i+cb_offset, cbdata)) {
610
0
            secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
611
0
            return 0;
612
0
        }
613
0
        secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&points[i], &point);
614
0
    }
615
0
    secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf(ctx, &state, r, n_points, points, scalars, inp_g_sc);
616
0
    secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
617
0
    return 1;
618
0
}
619
620
/* Wrapper for secp256k1_ecmult_multi_func interface */
621
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch_single(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context *actx, secp256k1_scratch *scratch, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *inp_g_sc, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void *cbdata, size_t n) {
622
0
    return secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch(error_callback, actx, scratch, r, inp_g_sc, cb, cbdata, n, 0);
623
0
}
624
625
0
static size_t secp256k1_strauss_max_points(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, secp256k1_scratch *scratch) {
626
0
    return secp256k1_scratch_max_allocation(error_callback, scratch, STRAUSS_SCRATCH_OBJECTS) / secp256k1_strauss_scratch_size(1);
627
0
}
628
629
/** Convert a number to WNAF notation.
630
 *  The number becomes represented by sum(2^{wi} * wnaf[i], i=0..WNAF_SIZE(w)+1) - return_val.
631
 *  It has the following guarantees:
632
 *  - each wnaf[i] is either 0 or an odd integer between -(1 << w) and (1 << w)
633
 *  - the number of words set is always WNAF_SIZE(w)
634
 *  - the returned skew is 0 or 1
635
 */
636
0
static int secp256k1_wnaf_fixed(int *wnaf, const secp256k1_scalar *s, int w) {
637
0
    int skew = 0;
638
0
    int pos;
639
0
    int max_pos;
640
0
    int last_w;
641
0
    const secp256k1_scalar *work = s;
642
0
643
0
    if (secp256k1_scalar_is_zero(s)) {
644
0
        for (pos = 0; pos < WNAF_SIZE(w); pos++) {
645
0
            wnaf[pos] = 0;
646
0
        }
647
0
        return 0;
648
0
    }
649
0
650
0
    if (secp256k1_scalar_is_even(s)) {
651
0
        skew = 1;
652
0
    }
653
0
654
0
    wnaf[0] = secp256k1_scalar_get_bits_var(work, 0, w) + skew;
655
0
    /* Compute last window size. Relevant when window size doesn't divide the
656
0
     * number of bits in the scalar */
657
0
    last_w = WNAF_BITS - (WNAF_SIZE(w) - 1) * w;
658
0
659
0
    /* Store the position of the first nonzero word in max_pos to allow
660
0
     * skipping leading zeros when calculating the wnaf. */
661
0
    for (pos = WNAF_SIZE(w) - 1; pos > 0; pos--) {
662
0
        int val = secp256k1_scalar_get_bits_var(work, pos * w, pos == WNAF_SIZE(w)-1 ? last_w : w);
663
0
        if(val != 0) {
664
0
            break;
665
0
        }
666
0
        wnaf[pos] = 0;
667
0
    }
668
0
    max_pos = pos;
669
0
    pos = 1;
670
0
671
0
    while (pos <= max_pos) {
672
0
        int val = secp256k1_scalar_get_bits_var(work, pos * w, pos == WNAF_SIZE(w)-1 ? last_w : w);
673
0
        if ((val & 1) == 0) {
674
0
            wnaf[pos - 1] -= (1 << w);
675
0
            wnaf[pos] = (val + 1);
676
0
        } else {
677
0
            wnaf[pos] = val;
678
0
        }
679
0
        /* Set a coefficient to zero if it is 1 or -1 and the proceeding digit
680
0
         * is strictly negative or strictly positive respectively. Only change
681
0
         * coefficients at previous positions because above code assumes that
682
0
         * wnaf[pos - 1] is odd.
683
0
         */
684
0
        if (pos >= 2 && ((wnaf[pos - 1] == 1 && wnaf[pos - 2] < 0) || (wnaf[pos - 1] == -1 && wnaf[pos - 2] > 0))) {
685
0
            if (wnaf[pos - 1] == 1) {
686
0
                wnaf[pos - 2] += 1 << w;
687
0
            } else {
688
0
                wnaf[pos - 2] -= 1 << w;
689
0
            }
690
0
            wnaf[pos - 1] = 0;
691
0
        }
692
0
        ++pos;
693
0
    }
694
0
695
0
    return skew;
696
0
}
697
698
struct secp256k1_pippenger_point_state {
699
    int skew_na;
700
    size_t input_pos;
701
};
702
703
struct secp256k1_pippenger_state {
704
    int *wnaf_na;
705
    struct secp256k1_pippenger_point_state* ps;
706
};
707
708
/*
709
 * pippenger_wnaf computes the result of a multi-point multiplication as
710
 * follows: The scalars are brought into wnaf with n_wnaf elements each. Then
711
 * for every i < n_wnaf, first each point is added to a "bucket" corresponding
712
 * to the point's wnaf[i]. Second, the buckets are added together such that
713
 * r += 1*bucket[0] + 3*bucket[1] + 5*bucket[2] + ...
714
 */
715
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_pippenger_wnaf(secp256k1_gej *buckets, int bucket_window, struct secp256k1_pippenger_state *state, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *sc, const secp256k1_ge *pt, size_t num) {
716
0
    size_t n_wnaf = WNAF_SIZE(bucket_window+1);
717
0
    size_t np;
718
0
    size_t no = 0;
719
0
    int i;
720
0
    int j;
721
0
722
0
    for (np = 0; np < num; ++np) {
723
0
        if (secp256k1_scalar_is_zero(&sc[np]) || secp256k1_ge_is_infinity(&pt[np])) {
724
0
            continue;
725
0
        }
726
0
        state->ps[no].input_pos = np;
727
0
        state->ps[no].skew_na = secp256k1_wnaf_fixed(&state->wnaf_na[no*n_wnaf], &sc[np], bucket_window+1);
728
0
        no++;
729
0
    }
730
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(r);
731
0
732
0
    if (no == 0) {
733
0
        return 1;
734
0
    }
735
0
736
0
    for (i = n_wnaf - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
737
0
        secp256k1_gej running_sum;
738
0
739
0
        for(j = 0; j < ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(bucket_window+2); j++) {
740
0
            secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(&buckets[j]);
741
0
        }
742
0
743
0
        for (np = 0; np < no; ++np) {
744
0
            int n = state->wnaf_na[np*n_wnaf + i];
745
0
            struct secp256k1_pippenger_point_state point_state = state->ps[np];
746
0
            secp256k1_ge tmp;
747
0
            int idx;
748
0
749
0
            if (i == 0) {
750
0
                /* correct for wnaf skew */
751
0
                int skew = point_state.skew_na;
752
0
                if (skew) {
753
0
                    secp256k1_ge_neg(&tmp, &pt[point_state.input_pos]);
754
0
                    secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(&buckets[0], &buckets[0], &tmp, NULL);
755
0
                }
756
0
            }
757
0
            if (n > 0) {
758
0
                idx = (n - 1)/2;
759
0
                secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(&buckets[idx], &buckets[idx], &pt[point_state.input_pos], NULL);
760
0
            } else if (n < 0) {
761
0
                idx = -(n + 1)/2;
762
0
                secp256k1_ge_neg(&tmp, &pt[point_state.input_pos]);
763
0
                secp256k1_gej_add_ge_var(&buckets[idx], &buckets[idx], &tmp, NULL);
764
0
            }
765
0
        }
766
0
767
0
        for(j = 0; j < bucket_window; j++) {
768
0
            secp256k1_gej_double_var(r, r, NULL);
769
0
        }
770
0
771
0
        secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(&running_sum);
772
0
        /* Accumulate the sum: bucket[0] + 3*bucket[1] + 5*bucket[2] + 7*bucket[3] + ...
773
0
         *                   = bucket[0] +   bucket[1] +   bucket[2] +   bucket[3] + ...
774
0
         *                   +         2 *  (bucket[1] + 2*bucket[2] + 3*bucket[3] + ...)
775
0
         * using an intermediate running sum:
776
0
         * running_sum = bucket[0] +   bucket[1] +   bucket[2] + ...
777
0
         *
778
0
         * The doubling is done implicitly by deferring the final window doubling (of 'r').
779
0
         */
780
0
        for(j = ECMULT_TABLE_SIZE(bucket_window+2) - 1; j > 0; j--) {
781
0
            secp256k1_gej_add_var(&running_sum, &running_sum, &buckets[j], NULL);
782
0
            secp256k1_gej_add_var(r, r, &running_sum, NULL);
783
0
        }
784
0
785
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_var(&running_sum, &running_sum, &buckets[0], NULL);
786
0
        secp256k1_gej_double_var(r, r, NULL);
787
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_var(r, r, &running_sum, NULL);
788
0
    }
789
0
    return 1;
790
0
}
791
792
/**
793
 * Returns optimal bucket_window (number of bits of a scalar represented by a
794
 * set of buckets) for a given number of points.
795
 */
796
0
static int secp256k1_pippenger_bucket_window(size_t n) {
797
0
    if (n <= 1) {
798
0
        return 1;
799
0
    } else if (n <= 4) {
800
0
        return 2;
801
0
    } else if (n <= 20) {
802
0
        return 3;
803
0
    } else if (n <= 57) {
804
0
        return 4;
805
0
    } else if (n <= 136) {
806
0
        return 5;
807
0
    } else if (n <= 235) {
808
0
        return 6;
809
0
    } else if (n <= 1260) {
810
0
        return 7;
811
0
    } else if (n <= 4420) {
812
0
        return 9;
813
0
    } else if (n <= 7880) {
814
0
        return 10;
815
0
    } else if (n <= 16050) {
816
0
        return 11;
817
0
    } else {
818
0
        return PIPPENGER_MAX_BUCKET_WINDOW;
819
0
    }
820
0
}
821
822
/**
823
 * Returns the maximum optimal number of points for a bucket_window.
824
 */
825
0
static size_t secp256k1_pippenger_bucket_window_inv(int bucket_window) {
826
0
    switch(bucket_window) {
827
0
        case 1: return 1;
828
0
        case 2: return 4;
829
0
        case 3: return 20;
830
0
        case 4: return 57;
831
0
        case 5: return 136;
832
0
        case 6: return 235;
833
0
        case 7: return 1260;
834
0
        case 8: return 1260;
835
0
        case 9: return 4420;
836
0
        case 10: return 7880;
837
0
        case 11: return 16050;
838
0
        case PIPPENGER_MAX_BUCKET_WINDOW: return SIZE_MAX;
839
0
    }
840
0
    return 0;
841
0
}
842
843
844
0
SECP256K1_INLINE static void secp256k1_ecmult_endo_split(secp256k1_scalar *s1, secp256k1_scalar *s2, secp256k1_ge *p1, secp256k1_ge *p2) {
845
0
    secp256k1_scalar tmp = *s1;
846
0
    secp256k1_scalar_split_lambda(s1, s2, &tmp);
847
0
    secp256k1_ge_mul_lambda(p2, p1);
848
0
849
0
    if (secp256k1_scalar_is_high(s1)) {
850
0
        secp256k1_scalar_negate(s1, s1);
851
0
        secp256k1_ge_neg(p1, p1);
852
0
    }
853
0
    if (secp256k1_scalar_is_high(s2)) {
854
0
        secp256k1_scalar_negate(s2, s2);
855
0
        secp256k1_ge_neg(p2, p2);
856
0
    }
857
0
}
858
859
/**
860
 * Returns the scratch size required for a given number of points (excluding
861
 * base point G) without considering alignment.
862
 */
863
0
static size_t secp256k1_pippenger_scratch_size(size_t n_points, int bucket_window) {
864
0
    size_t entries = 2*n_points + 2;
865
0
    size_t entry_size = sizeof(secp256k1_ge) + sizeof(secp256k1_scalar) + sizeof(struct secp256k1_pippenger_point_state) + (WNAF_SIZE(bucket_window+1)+1)*sizeof(int);
866
0
    return (sizeof(secp256k1_gej) << bucket_window) + sizeof(struct secp256k1_pippenger_state) + entries * entry_size;
867
0
}
868
869
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_pippenger_batch(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, secp256k1_scratch *scratch, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *inp_g_sc, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void *cbdata, size_t n_points, size_t cb_offset) {
870
0
    const size_t scratch_checkpoint = secp256k1_scratch_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch);
871
0
    /* Use 2(n+1) with the endomorphism, when calculating batch
872
0
     * sizes. The reason for +1 is that we add the G scalar to the list of
873
0
     * other scalars. */
874
0
    size_t entries = 2*n_points + 2;
875
0
    secp256k1_ge *points;
876
0
    secp256k1_scalar *scalars;
877
0
    secp256k1_gej *buckets;
878
0
    struct secp256k1_pippenger_state *state_space;
879
0
    size_t idx = 0;
880
0
    size_t point_idx = 0;
881
0
    int i, j;
882
0
    int bucket_window;
883
0
884
0
    (void)ctx;
885
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(r);
886
0
    if (inp_g_sc == NULL && n_points == 0) {
887
0
        return 1;
888
0
    }
889
0
890
0
    bucket_window = secp256k1_pippenger_bucket_window(n_points);
891
0
    points = (secp256k1_ge *) secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, entries * sizeof(*points));
892
0
    scalars = (secp256k1_scalar *) secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, entries * sizeof(*scalars));
893
0
    state_space = (struct secp256k1_pippenger_state *) secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, sizeof(*state_space));
894
0
    if (points == NULL || scalars == NULL || state_space == NULL) {
895
0
        secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
896
0
        return 0;
897
0
    }
898
0
899
0
    state_space->ps = (struct secp256k1_pippenger_point_state *) secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, entries * sizeof(*state_space->ps));
900
0
    state_space->wnaf_na = (int *) secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, entries*(WNAF_SIZE(bucket_window+1)) * sizeof(int));
901
0
    buckets = (secp256k1_gej *) secp256k1_scratch_alloc(error_callback, scratch, (1<<bucket_window) * sizeof(*buckets));
902
0
    if (state_space->ps == NULL || state_space->wnaf_na == NULL || buckets == NULL) {
903
0
        secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
904
0
        return 0;
905
0
    }
906
0
907
0
    if (inp_g_sc != NULL) {
908
0
        scalars[0] = *inp_g_sc;
909
0
        points[0] = secp256k1_ge_const_g;
910
0
        idx++;
911
0
        secp256k1_ecmult_endo_split(&scalars[0], &scalars[1], &points[0], &points[1]);
912
0
        idx++;
913
0
    }
914
0
915
0
    while (point_idx < n_points) {
916
0
        if (!cb(&scalars[idx], &points[idx], point_idx + cb_offset, cbdata)) {
917
0
            secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
918
0
            return 0;
919
0
        }
920
0
        idx++;
921
0
        secp256k1_ecmult_endo_split(&scalars[idx - 1], &scalars[idx], &points[idx - 1], &points[idx]);
922
0
        idx++;
923
0
        point_idx++;
924
0
    }
925
0
926
0
    secp256k1_ecmult_pippenger_wnaf(buckets, bucket_window, state_space, r, scalars, points, idx);
927
0
928
0
    /* Clear data */
929
0
    for(i = 0; (size_t)i < idx; i++) {
930
0
        secp256k1_scalar_clear(&scalars[i]);
931
0
        state_space->ps[i].skew_na = 0;
932
0
        for(j = 0; j < WNAF_SIZE(bucket_window+1); j++) {
933
0
            state_space->wnaf_na[i * WNAF_SIZE(bucket_window+1) + j] = 0;
934
0
        }
935
0
    }
936
0
    for(i = 0; i < 1<<bucket_window; i++) {
937
0
        secp256k1_gej_clear(&buckets[i]);
938
0
    }
939
0
    secp256k1_scratch_apply_checkpoint(error_callback, scratch, scratch_checkpoint);
940
0
    return 1;
941
0
}
942
943
/* Wrapper for secp256k1_ecmult_multi_func interface */
944
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_pippenger_batch_single(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context *actx, secp256k1_scratch *scratch, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *inp_g_sc, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void *cbdata, size_t n) {
945
0
    return secp256k1_ecmult_pippenger_batch(error_callback, actx, scratch, r, inp_g_sc, cb, cbdata, n, 0);
946
0
}
947
948
/**
949
 * Returns the maximum number of points in addition to G that can be used with
950
 * a given scratch space. The function ensures that fewer points may also be
951
 * used.
952
 */
953
0
static size_t secp256k1_pippenger_max_points(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, secp256k1_scratch *scratch) {
954
0
    size_t max_alloc = secp256k1_scratch_max_allocation(error_callback, scratch, PIPPENGER_SCRATCH_OBJECTS);
955
0
    int bucket_window;
956
0
    size_t res = 0;
957
0
958
0
    for (bucket_window = 1; bucket_window <= PIPPENGER_MAX_BUCKET_WINDOW; bucket_window++) {
959
0
        size_t n_points;
960
0
        size_t max_points = secp256k1_pippenger_bucket_window_inv(bucket_window);
961
0
        size_t space_for_points;
962
0
        size_t space_overhead;
963
0
        size_t entry_size = sizeof(secp256k1_ge) + sizeof(secp256k1_scalar) + sizeof(struct secp256k1_pippenger_point_state) + (WNAF_SIZE(bucket_window+1)+1)*sizeof(int);
964
0
965
0
        entry_size = 2*entry_size;
966
0
        space_overhead = (sizeof(secp256k1_gej) << bucket_window) + entry_size + sizeof(struct secp256k1_pippenger_state);
967
0
        if (space_overhead > max_alloc) {
968
0
            break;
969
0
        }
970
0
        space_for_points = max_alloc - space_overhead;
971
0
972
0
        n_points = space_for_points/entry_size;
973
0
        n_points = n_points > max_points ? max_points : n_points;
974
0
        if (n_points > res) {
975
0
            res = n_points;
976
0
        }
977
0
        if (n_points < max_points) {
978
0
            /* A larger bucket_window may support even more points. But if we
979
0
             * would choose that then the caller couldn't safely use any number
980
0
             * smaller than what this function returns */
981
0
            break;
982
0
        }
983
0
    }
984
0
    return res;
985
0
}
986
987
/* Computes ecmult_multi by simply multiplying and adding each point. Does not
988
 * require a scratch space */
989
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_multi_simple_var(const secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *inp_g_sc, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void *cbdata, size_t n_points) {
990
0
    size_t point_idx;
991
0
    secp256k1_scalar szero;
992
0
    secp256k1_gej tmpj;
993
0
994
0
    secp256k1_scalar_set_int(&szero, 0);
995
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(r);
996
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(&tmpj);
997
0
    /* r = inp_g_sc*G */
998
0
    secp256k1_ecmult(ctx, r, &tmpj, &szero, inp_g_sc);
999
0
    for (point_idx = 0; point_idx < n_points; point_idx++) {
1000
0
        secp256k1_ge point;
1001
0
        secp256k1_gej pointj;
1002
0
        secp256k1_scalar scalar;
1003
0
        if (!cb(&scalar, &point, point_idx, cbdata)) {
1004
0
            return 0;
1005
0
        }
1006
0
        /* r += scalar*point */
1007
0
        secp256k1_gej_set_ge(&pointj, &point);
1008
0
        secp256k1_ecmult(ctx, &tmpj, &pointj, &scalar, NULL);
1009
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_var(r, r, &tmpj, NULL);
1010
0
    }
1011
0
    return 1;
1012
0
}
1013
1014
/* Compute the number of batches and the batch size given the maximum batch size and the
1015
 * total number of points */
1016
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_multi_batch_size_helper(size_t *n_batches, size_t *n_batch_points, size_t max_n_batch_points, size_t n) {
1017
0
    if (max_n_batch_points == 0) {
1018
0
        return 0;
1019
0
    }
1020
0
    if (max_n_batch_points > ECMULT_MAX_POINTS_PER_BATCH) {
1021
0
        max_n_batch_points = ECMULT_MAX_POINTS_PER_BATCH;
1022
0
    }
1023
0
    if (n == 0) {
1024
0
        *n_batches = 0;
1025
0
        *n_batch_points = 0;
1026
0
        return 1;
1027
0
    }
1028
0
    /* Compute ceil(n/max_n_batch_points) and ceil(n/n_batches) */
1029
0
    *n_batches = 1 + (n - 1) / max_n_batch_points;
1030
0
    *n_batch_points = 1 + (n - 1) / *n_batches;
1031
0
    return 1;
1032
0
}
1033
1034
typedef int (*secp256k1_ecmult_multi_func)(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context*, secp256k1_scratch*, secp256k1_gej*, const secp256k1_scalar*, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void*, size_t);
1035
0
static int secp256k1_ecmult_multi_var(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context *ctx, secp256k1_scratch *scratch, secp256k1_gej *r, const secp256k1_scalar *inp_g_sc, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void *cbdata, size_t n) {
1036
0
    size_t i;
1037
0
1038
0
    int (*f)(const secp256k1_callback* error_callback, const secp256k1_ecmult_context*, secp256k1_scratch*, secp256k1_gej*, const secp256k1_scalar*, secp256k1_ecmult_multi_callback cb, void*, size_t, size_t);
1039
0
    size_t n_batches;
1040
0
    size_t n_batch_points;
1041
0
1042
0
    secp256k1_gej_set_infinity(r);
1043
0
    if (inp_g_sc == NULL && n == 0) {
1044
0
        return 1;
1045
0
    } else if (n == 0) {
1046
0
        secp256k1_scalar szero;
1047
0
        secp256k1_scalar_set_int(&szero, 0);
1048
0
        secp256k1_ecmult(ctx, r, r, &szero, inp_g_sc);
1049
0
        return 1;
1050
0
    }
1051
0
    if (scratch == NULL) {
1052
0
        return secp256k1_ecmult_multi_simple_var(ctx, r, inp_g_sc, cb, cbdata, n);
1053
0
    }
1054
0
1055
0
    /* Compute the batch sizes for Pippenger's algorithm given a scratch space. If it's greater than
1056
0
     * a threshold use Pippenger's algorithm. Otherwise use Strauss' algorithm.
1057
0
     * As a first step check if there's enough space for Pippenger's algo (which requires less space
1058
0
     * than Strauss' algo) and if not, use the simple algorithm. */
1059
0
    if (!secp256k1_ecmult_multi_batch_size_helper(&n_batches, &n_batch_points, secp256k1_pippenger_max_points(error_callback, scratch), n)) {
1060
0
        return secp256k1_ecmult_multi_simple_var(ctx, r, inp_g_sc, cb, cbdata, n);
1061
0
    }
1062
0
    if (n_batch_points >= ECMULT_PIPPENGER_THRESHOLD) {
1063
0
        f = secp256k1_ecmult_pippenger_batch;
1064
0
    } else {
1065
0
        if (!secp256k1_ecmult_multi_batch_size_helper(&n_batches, &n_batch_points, secp256k1_strauss_max_points(error_callback, scratch), n)) {
1066
0
            return secp256k1_ecmult_multi_simple_var(ctx, r, inp_g_sc, cb, cbdata, n);
1067
0
        }
1068
0
        f = secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch;
1069
0
    }
1070
0
    for(i = 0; i < n_batches; i++) {
1071
0
        size_t nbp = n < n_batch_points ? n : n_batch_points;
1072
0
        size_t offset = n_batch_points*i;
1073
0
        secp256k1_gej tmp;
1074
0
        if (!f(error_callback, ctx, scratch, &tmp, i == 0 ? inp_g_sc : NULL, cb, cbdata, nbp, offset)) {
1075
0
            return 0;
1076
0
        }
1077
0
        secp256k1_gej_add_var(r, r, &tmp, NULL);
1078
0
        n -= nbp;
1079
0
    }
1080
0
    return 1;
1081
0
}

1083
#endif /* SECP256K1_ECMULT_IMPL_H */

#ifndef SECP256K1_FIELD_REPR_H
8
#define SECP256K1_FIELD_REPR_H
9

#include <stdint.h>
11
12
typedef struct {
13
    /* X = sum(i=0..4, n[i]*2^(i*52)) mod p
14
     * where p = 2^256 - 0x1000003D1
15
     */
16
    uint64_t n[5];
17
#ifdef VERIFY
18
    int magnitude;
19
    int normalized;
20
#endif
21
} secp256k1_fe;
22
23
/* Unpacks a constant into a overlapping multi-limbed FE element. */
24
112
#define SECP256K1_FE_CONST_INNER(d7, d6, d5, d4, d3, d2, d1, d0) { \
25
112
    (d0) | (((uint64_t)(d1) & 0xFFFFFUL) << 32), \
26
112
    ((uint64_t)(d1) >> 20) | (((uint64_t)(d2)) << 12) | (((uint64_t)(d3) & 0xFFUL) << 44), \
27
112
    ((uint64_t)(d3) >> 8) | (((uint64_t)(d4) & 0xFFFFFFFUL) << 24), \
28
112
    ((uint64_t)(d4) >> 28) | (((uint64_t)(d5)) << 4) | (((uint64_t)(d6) & 0xFFFFUL) << 36), \
29
112
    ((uint64_t)(d6) >> 16) | (((uint64_t)(d7)) << 16) \
30
112
}
31
32
#ifdef VERIFY
33
#define SECP256K1_FE_CONST(d7, d6, d5, d4, d3, d2, d1, d0) {SECP256K1_FE_CONST_INNER((d7), (d6), (d5), (d4), (d3), (d2), (d1), (d0)), 1, 1}
34
#else
35
112
#define SECP256K1_FE_CONST(d7, d6, d5, d4, d3, d2, d1, d0) {SECP256K1_FE_CONST_INNER((d7), (d6), (d5), (d4), (d3), (d2), (d1), (d0))}
36
#endif
37
38
typedef struct {
39
    uint64_t n[4];
40
} secp256k1_fe_storage;
41
42
#define SECP256K1_FE_STORAGE_CONST(d7, d6, d5, d4, d3, d2, d1, d0) {{ \
43
    (d0) | (((uint64_t)(d1)) << 32), \
44
    (d2) | (((uint64_t)(d3)) << 32), \
45
    (d4) | (((uint64_t)(d5)) << 32), \
46
    (d6) | (((uint64_t)(d7)) << 32) \
47
}}
48
49
#define SECP256K1_FE_STORAGE_CONST_GET(d) \
50
    (uint32_t)(d.n[3] >> 32), (uint32_t)d.n[3], \
51
    (uint32_t)(d.n[2] >> 32), (uint32_t)d.n[2], \
52
    (uint32_t)(d.n[1] >> 32), (uint32_t)d.n[1], \
53
    (uint32_t)(d.n[0] >> 32), (uint32_t)d.n[0]

/***********************************************************************

7
#ifndef SECP256K1_FIELD_REPR_IMPL_H
8
#define SECP256K1_FIELD_REPR_IMPL_H
9
10
#if defined HAVE_CONFIG_H
11
#include "libsecp256k1-config.h"
12
#endif
13
14
#include "util.h"
15
#include "field.h"
16
#include "modinv64_impl.h"
17
18
#if defined(USE_ASM_X86_64)
19
#include "field_5x52_asm_impl.h"
20
#else
21
#include "field_5x52_int128_impl.h"
22
#endif
23
24
/** Implements arithmetic modulo FFFFFFFF FFFFFFFF FFFFFFFF FFFFFFFF FFFFFFFF FFFFFFFF FFFFFFFE FFFFFC2F,
25
 *  represented as 5 uint64_t's in base 2^52. The values are allowed to contain >52 each. In particular,
26
 *  each FieldElem has a 'magnitude' associated with it. Internally, a magnitude M means each element
27
 *  is at most M*(2^53-1), except the most significant one, which is limited to M*(2^49-1). All operations
28
 *  accept any input with magnitude at most M, and have different rules for propagating magnitude to their
29
 *  output.
30
 */
31
32
#ifdef VERIFY
33
static void secp256k1_fe_verify(const secp256k1_fe *a) {
34
    const uint64_t *d = a->n;
35
    int m = a->normalized ? 1 : 2 * a->magnitude, r = 1;
36
   /* secp256k1 'p' value defined in "Standards for Efficient Cryptography" (SEC2) 2.7.1. */
37
    r &= (d[0] <= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL * m);
38
    r &= (d[1] <= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL * m);
39
    r &= (d[2] <= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL * m);
40
    r &= (d[3] <= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL * m);
41
    r &= (d[4] <= 0x0FFFFFFFFFFFFULL * m);
42
    r &= (a->magnitude >= 0);
43
    r &= (a->magnitude <= 2048);
44
    if (a->normalized) {
45
        r &= (a->magnitude <= 1);
46
        if (r && (d[4] == 0x0FFFFFFFFFFFFULL) && ((d[3] & d[2] & d[1]) == 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL)) {
47
            r &= (d[0] < 0xFFFFEFFFFFC2FULL);
48
        }
49
    }
50
    VERIFY_CHECK(r == 1);
51
}
52
#endif
53
54
34.8k
static void secp256k1_fe_normalize(secp256k1_fe *r) {
55
34.8k
    uint64_t t0 = r->n[0], t1 = r->n[1], t2 = r->n[2], t3 = r->n[3], t4 = r->n[4];
56
57
    /* Reduce t4 at the start so there will be at most a single carry from the first pass */
58
34.8k
    uint64_t m;
59
34.8k
    uint64_t x = t4 >> 48; t4 &= 0x0FFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
60
61
    /* The first pass ensures the magnitude is 1, ... */
62
34.8k
    t0 += x * 0x1000003D1ULL;
63
34.8k
    t1 += (t0 >> 52); t0 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
64
34.8k
    t2 += (t1 >> 52); t1 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL; m = t1;
65
34.8k
    t3 += (t2 >> 52); t2 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL; m &= t2;
66
34.8k
    t4 += (t3 >> 52); t3 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL; m &= t3;
67
68
    /* ... except for a possible carry at bit 48 of t4 (i.e. bit 256 of the field element) */
69
34.8k
    VERIFY_CHECK(t4 >> 49 == 0);
70
71
    /* At most a single final reduction is needed; check if the value is >= the field characteristic */
72
34.8k
    x = (t4 >> 48) | ((t4 == 0x0FFFFFFFFFFFFULL) & (m == 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL)
73
34.8k
        & (t0 >= 0xFFFFEFFFFFC2FULL));
74
75
    /* Apply the final reduction (for constant-time behaviour, we do it always) */
76
34.8k
    t0 += x * 0x1000003D1ULL;
77
34.8k
    t1 += (t0 >> 52); t0 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
78
34.8k
    t2 += (t1 >> 52); t1 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
79
34.8k
    t3 += (t2 >> 52); t2 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
80
34.8k
    t4 += (t3 >> 52); t3 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
81
82
    /* If t4 didn't carry to bit 48 already, then it should have after any final reduction */
83
34.8k
    VERIFY_CHECK(t4 >> 48 == x);
84
85
    /* Mask off the possible multiple of 2^256 from the final reduction */
86
34.8k
    t4 &= 0x0FFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
87
88
34.8k
    r->n[0] = t0; r->n[1] = t1; r->n[2] = t2; r->n[3] = t3; r->n[4] = t4;
89
90
#ifdef VERIFY
91
    r->magnitude = 1;
92
    r->normalized = 1;
93
    secp256k1_fe_verify(r);
94
#endif
95
34.8k
}
96
97
33.8k
static void secp256k1_fe_normalize_weak(secp256k1_fe *r) {
98
33.8k
    uint64_t t0 = r->n[0], t1 = r->n[1], t2 = r->n[2], t3 = r->n[3], t4 = r->n[4];
99
100
    /* Reduce t4 at the start so there will be at most a single carry from the first pass */
101
33.8k
    uint64_t x = t4 >> 48; t4 &= 0x0FFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
102
103
    /* The first pass ensures the magnitude is 1, ... */
104
33.8k
    t0 += x * 0x1000003D1ULL;
105
33.8k
    t1 += (t0 >> 52); t0 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
106
33.8k
    t2 += (t1 >> 52); t1 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
107
33.8k
    t3 += (t2 >> 52); t2 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
108
33.8k
    t4 += (t3 >> 52); t3 &= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
109
110
    /* ... except for a possible carry at bit 48 of t4 (i.e. bit 256 of the field element) */
111
33.8k
    VERIFY_CHECK(t4 >> 49 == 0);
112
113
33.8k
    r->n[0] = t0; r->n[1] = t1; r->n[2] = t2; r->n[3] = t3; r->n[4] = t4;
114
115
#ifdef VERIFY
116
    r->magnitude = 1;
117
    secp256k1_fe_verify(r);
118
#endif
119
33.8k
}
